intro.title: Separating the Wind from the Waves
description: The rough waves crashing over you right now were created by the wind called 'thoughts.'
To avoid being swept away by the waves, you need to take a step back from the wind shaking your surface.
Just realizing that the wind is what causes the waves will begin to ease the power of your anxiety.
intro.contentDescription: Let's practice understanding and separating thoughts from objective facts.
steps: 1. Write it down: Write the thoughts making you anxious into a sentence.
2. Separate thoughts: Drag and select the 'thought' part that isn't a fact.
3. Let it flow: Watch the selected thought fade away, leaving only the objective fact behind.
intro.tip: Tip: The wind can shake your surface, but it can never reach the depths of your ocean. Just calmly watch the wind as it blows by.

title: What thoughts are
floating in your head?
step1.description: Write down the voices in your head exactly as they sound, without judgment. Long or short, any sentence is fine.
step1.placeholder: e.g., "I'll never get anything right," "What if everyone hates me?"

title: How much of this sentence
is just a 'thought'?
step2.description: Drag and select only the part that is an interpretation or a judgment.

title: You've separated the waves and the wind
description: Just like the text that turned transparent, the wind of thoughts only brushes across your ocean for a moment.
As the wind loses its strength, the rough waves will soon settle into a calm stillness.
